unnormalised: Hey there! So, you're planning a trip and budgeting for it, huh? Travel can be expensive, especially if you’re not careful with your Rupees. For a domestic trip, let's say a week in Goa, you could easily spend ₹20,000-₹30,000 per person, that includes travel, stay and food. Flights alone from Delhi could cost around Rs. 4,000 - ₹7,000 each way, depending on when you book. Always compare prices on different websites!
normalised: Hey there! So, you are planning a trip and budgeting for it, huh? Travel can be expensive, especially if you are not careful with your Rupees. For a domestic trip, let's say a week in Goa, you could easily spend rupee twenty thousand to rupee thirty thousand per person, that includes travel, stay and food. Flights alone from Delhi could cost around rupee four thousand to rupee seven thousand each way, depending on when you book. Always compare prices on different websites!

unnormalised: Accommodation can vary widely. A decent guesthouse might be ₹800-₹1500 per night, while a fancy resort can easily cross Rs 5000/night. Then there's food. Street food is yummy and cheap (think Rs. 100-Rs. 200 per meal), but restaurant meals can be Rs. 500 and upwards. Don’t forget to factor in local transport – auto-rickshaws can add up to ₹200-₹300 a day if you're moving around a lot.
normalised: Accommodation can vary widely. A decent guesthouse might be rupee eight hundred to rupee one thousand five hundred per night, while a fancy resort can easily cross rupee five thousand per night. Then there's food. Street food is yummy and cheap (think rupee one hundred to rupee two hundred per meal), but restaurant meals can be rupee five hundred and upwards. Don't forget to factor in local transport – auto-rickshaws can add up to rupee two hundred to rupee three hundred a day if you are moving around a lot.

unnormalised: For international trips, obviously, the budget jumps considerably. A trip to Thailand might cost anywhere from $500-$1000 (that's approximately Rs. 41,500 - ₹83,000, give or take, depending on the exchange rate), excluding flights! Visas, travel insurance, and international roaming charges also need to be added to your expenses. Pro tip: Keep an eye on forex rates to get the best deals when converting your INR to USD or other currencies. Happy travels!
